clusters.title: Man arrested after minivan chase in Melbourne
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Arrested After Minivan Pursuit and Alleged Collisions
bullet_summary: Reported by 9News, The Age, Canberra Times

items.title: Man arrested after minivan chase in Melbourne
items.standfirst: T he van driver allegedly collided head on with another car after police called off a pursuit.
items.content: A man is under police guard in hospital after a minivan chase in Melbourne early this morning.Police spotted the van, which they allege was of interest in an ongoing investigation, travelling on Leakes Road, Truganina, at about 4am. Officers covertly followed the van along the West Gate Freeway until it exited at the Kings Way off-ramp and started travelling toward the city.READ MORE: Charges three months after 'amazing' man killed in alleged hit-run Police deployed stop sticks on Kings Way, which slowed the van, but the driver allegedly refused to pull over. A pursuit began but was called off when the van crossed onto the wrong side of the road.A short time later, the van collided head-on with a car on the Kings Way Bridge.The van driver suffered non-life-threatening injuries and was taken to hospital under police guard. READ MORE: 'Deeply troubling': Author's dogged pursuit of the truth 50 years after Whitlam dismissal Two males in the car suffered injuries and were treated at the scene.Police allegedly found a large amount of drugs in the van.Kings Way remains shut in both directions this morning and an investigation is underway. Any witnesses or anybody with footage is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or online. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: Officers attempted to arrest him in Fyshwick on an outstanding warrant.

clusters.title: '100 per cent innocent': AFL star cleared on rape claim, calls for investigation
clusters.neutral_headline: AFL Star Cleared of Rape Allegations, Calls for Investigation

items.title: '100 per cent innocent': AFL star cleared on rape claim, calls for investigation
items.standfirst: Geelong AFL star Tanner Bruhn has proclaimed his innocence, calling on police to investigate those who made dumped rape allegations against him.
items.content: Geelong AFL star Tanner Bruhn has proclaimed his innocence, calling on police to investigate those who made dumped rape allegations against him.Prosecutors withdrew charges against Bruhn and his co-accused Patrick Sinnott today after the pair fought claims they raped a woman in February 2023.Bruhn's identity had been suppressed throughout the court proceedings but his barrister Dermot Dann KC asked for the order to be lifted.READ MORE: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy released from prison pending appealHe said the complainant had since admitted she lied and the case was clearly a "horrible stain on the criminal justice system"."(Bruhn) should be regarded now and forever as someone who was 100 per cent innocent," Dann told Geelong Magistrates Court today.Prosecutors alleged Bruhn and Sinnott raped the woman, who cannot be legally identified, in the early hours of February 5, 2023 after attending a strip club in Geelong, south-west of Melbourne.They alleged the two men left the club with the complainant in her car and the assault happened in a Dan Murphy's car park in the nearby suburb of Belmont.CCTV footage showed the woman leaving the strip club with the men at 4.17am and then her car arriving at the car park at 4.21am.The alleged rape was not captured on the vision, but the woman's vehicle was seen leaving the area about 5am.During a committal hearing in September, a male prosecution witness told the court the woman later admitted to lying in her police statement.She told the man she had an agreement with Bruhn and Sinnott and it was consensual, but something happened she didn't agree with, the court heard.The man said the complainant told him to lie in his statement to police and in his evidence before the court.The woman was scheduled to give evidence today before the charges were dropped.Bruhn's lawyer Anna Balmer said her client wanted those behind the allegations to be investigated."Tanner wants to see those responsible for making these false allegations held to account," she told reporters outside court."We should all hope that Victoria Police properly investigates what appears to be an attempt to pervert the course of justice by at least one, if not two, prosecution witnesses."The AFL confirmed Bruhn had been stood down from playing in the AFL or VFL while the allegations were before the courts.Bruhn said he was keen to get back to playing football."Tanner wants to put this nightmare behind him," Balmer said."He's hopeful for the future and looking forward to getting back to doing what he loves."The Geelong Football Club confirmed Bruhn would return to its program for the start of pre-season training."While legal proceedings have been ongoing, the club has provided professional welfare to Tanner during this time and will continue to do so," a club statement read.Lawyers for Sinnott also spoke outside court, noting he had suffered the brunt of public scrutiny while his co-accused's identity was suppressed."The impact has been deep and far-reaching," lawyer Holly Boylan said."Patrick now asks to be allowed to move forward in his life."The AFL Players Association welcomed the charges being dropped after a "long and flawed process".While Geelong had been exemplary in its care for Tanner during the court process, the association described an AFL decision to stand him down after charges were laid as "premature and disproportionate".Early in the 2025 season, Tanner was listed as unavailable with a finger injury before being removed from the injury list altogether.Unlike the NRL or Football Australia, the AFL does not have an official no-fault stand-down policy.National Sexual Assault, Domestic Family Violence Counselling Service 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).National Sexual Abuse and Redress Support Service 1800 211 028Help is available from the Men's Referral Service on 1300 766 491.
